in the early 1500s, where enslaved Africans cultivated
them in plots alongside sugar plantations. There were many different bananas, most of which looked nothing like
the bananas in supermarket aisles today. In the 1800s, captains 
from New Orleans and New England ventured to the Caribbean in search 
of coconuts and other goods. They began to experiment with bananas,
purchasing one kind, called Gros Michel, from Afro-Caribbean
farmers in Jamaica, Cuba, and Honduras. Gros Michel bananas produced large bunches
of relatively thick-skinned fruit— ideal for shipping. By the end of the 1800s, 
bananas were a hit in the US. They were affordable, 
available year-round, and endorsed by medical doctors. As bananas became big business, U.S. fruit companies wanted 
to grow their own bananas. In order to secure access to land, banana moguls lobbied and bribed
government officials in Central America, and even funded coups to ensure 
they had allies in power. In Honduras, Manuel Bonilla repaid 
the banana man who had financed his return to power
with land concessions. By the 1930s, one company dominated
the region: United Fruit, who owned over 40% of Guatemala’s 
arable land at one point. They cleared rainforest in Costa Rica,
Colombia, Guatemala, Honduras, and Panama to build plantations, along with railroads, ports, 
and towns to house workers. Lured by relatively high-paying jobs,
people migrated to banana zones. From Guatemala to Colombia, United Fruit’s plantations grew
exclusively Gros Michel bananas. These densely packed farms 
had little biological diversity, making them ripe for disease epidemics. The infrastructure connecting 
these vulnerable farms could quickly spread disease: pathogens could hitch a ride from one
farm to another on workers’ boots, railroad cars, and steamships. That’s exactly what happened in the 1910s, when a fungus began to level 
Gros Michel banana plantations, first in Panama, and later throughout
Central America, spreading quickly via the same system that
had enabled big profits and cheap bananas. In a race against “Panama Disease,” banana companies abandoned 
infected plantations in Costa Rica, Honduras, and Guatemala, leaving thousands of farmers and workers 
jobless. The companies then felled 
extensive tracts of rainforests in order to establish new plantations. After World War II, the dictatorships with which United Fruit
had partnered in Guatemala and Honduras yielded to democratically elected
governments that called for land reform. In Guatemala, President Jacobo Arbenz
tried to buy back land from United Fruit and redistribute it to landless farmers. The Arbenz government offered to pay
a price based on tax records— where United Fruit had underreported
the value of the land. El Pulpo was not happy. The company launched propaganda
campaigns against Arbenz and called on its deep connections 
in the US Government for help. Citing fears of communism,
the CIA orchestrated the overthrow of the democratically elected 
Arbenz in 1954. That same year in Honduras, thousands
of United Fruit workers went on strike until the company agreed to recognize
a new labor union. With the political and economic costs 
of running from Panama Disease escalating, United Fruit finally switched 
from Gros Michel to Panama disease-resistant Cavendish
bananas in the early 1960s. Today, bananas are no longer 
as economically vital in Central America, and United Fruit Company, 
rechristened Chiquita, has lost its stranglehold
on Latin American politics. But the modern banana industry
isn’t without problems. Cavendish bananas require frequent
applications of pesticides that create hazards for farmworkers 
and ecosystems. And though they’re resistant 
to the particular pathogen that affected Gros Michel bananas, Cavendish farms 
also lack biological diversity, leaving the banana trade 
ripe for another pandemic.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why did United Fruit switch from Gros Michel to Cavenish bananas?
Options: A. Cavendish bananas were resistant to Panama Disease, B. Consumers preferred the taste of Cavendish bananas, C. Cavendish bananas required fewer pesticides than Gros Michel, D. Communists did not like the taste of Cavendish bananas.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the exiled former leader of Honduras that boarded a borrowed yacht in New Orleans in 1910? Options: A. Jacobo Arbenz, B. Manuel Bonilla, C. A U.S. fruit company executive, D. A captain from New Orleans Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the nickname given to the United Fruit Company due to its long reach in Latin America? Options: A. El Pulpo (The Snake), B. El Pulpo (The Octopus), C. The Banana Empire, D. The Fruit Giant Correct Option: None
Question 3: Where were bananas first cultivated thousands of years ago? Options: A. The Americas, B. Southeast Asia, C. Africa, D. Central America Correct Option: None
Question 4: What type of banana was cultivated by United Fruit Company in the early 20th century? Options: A. Cavendish, B. Gros Michel, C. Panama, D. Chiquita Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why did the United Fruit Company clear rainforests in Central America? Options: A. To build ports and towns, B. To establish new plantations, C. To harvest coconuts, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the name of the disease that affected Gros Michel banana plantations in the 1910s? Options: A. Panama Disease, B. Banana Blight, C. Fruit Fungus, D. Plantation Plague Correct Option: None
Question 7: Who was the President of Guatemala that tried to buy back land from United Fruit and redistribute it to landless farmers? Options: A. Manuel Bonilla, B. Jacobo Arbenz, C. A U.S. fruit company executive, D. A CIA operative Correct Option: None
Question 8: What event occurred in 1954 in Guatemala? Options: A. The CIA orchestrated the overthrow of President Jacobo Arbenz, B. The United Fruit Company switched to Cavendish bananas, C. Thousands of United Fruit workers went on strike, D. Manuel Bonilla regained power Correct Option: None
Question 9: Why did the United Fruit Company switch from Gros Michel to Cavendish bananas in the early 1960s? Options: A. Cavendish bananas were more profitable, B. Cavendish bananas were resistant to Panama Disease, C. Cavendish bananas required less pesticides, D. Cavendish bananas were more popular in the US Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is a current problem facing the modern banana industry? Options: A. Lack of biological diversity, B. Over-reliance on pesticides, C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to ask why the United Fruit Company switched from Gros Michel to Cavendish bananas. The correct option in both questions is also the same, which is that Cavendish bananas were resistant to Panama Disease. 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 9

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Standing at almost 84 meters tall, this is the largest known living tree
on the planet. Nicknamed General Sherman, this giant sequoia has sequestered
roughly 1,400 tons of atmospheric carbon over its estimated 2,500 years on earth. Very few trees can compete 
with this carbon impact, but today, humanity produces more 
than 1,400 tons of carbon every minute. To combat climate change, we need to steeply reduce 
fossil fuel emissions, and draw down excess CO2 
to restore our atmosphere’s balance of greenhouse gases. But what can trees do to help
in this fight? And how do they sequester carbon 
in the first place? Like all plants, trees consume
atmospheric carbon through a chemical reaction 
called photosynthesis. This process uses energy 
from sunlight to convert water and carbon dioxide 
into oxygen and energy-storing carbohydrates. Plants then consume 
these carbohydrates in a reverse process called respiration, 
converting them to energy and releasing carbon 
back into the atmosphere. In trees, however, a large portion
of that carbon isn’t released, and instead, is stored 
as newly formed wood tissue. During their lifetimes, 
trees act as carbon vaults, and they continue to draw down carbon 
for as long as they grow. However, when a tree dies
and decays, some of its carbon will be released
back into the air. A significant amount of CO2
is stored in the soil, where it can remain 
for thousands of years. But eventually, that carbon
also seeps back into the atmosphere. So if trees are going to help 
fight a long-term problem like climate change, they need to survive to sequester 
their carbon for the longest period possible, 
while also reproducing quickly. Is there one type of tree 
we could plant that meets these criteria? Some fast growing, long-lived, 
super sequestering species we could scatter worldwide? Not that we know of. But even if such a tree existed, it wouldn’t be a good 
long-term solution. Forests are complex networks 
of living organisms, and there’s no one species 
that can thrive in every ecosystem. The most sustainable trees to plant 
are always native ones; species that already play a role 
in their local environment. Preliminary research shows 
that ecosystems with a naturally occurring diversity
of trees have less competition for resources and better resist
climate change. This means we can’t just plant trees 
to draw down carbon; we need to restore depleted ecosystems. There are numerous regions
that have been clear cut or developed that are ripe for restoring. In 2019, a study led 
by Zurich’s Crowtherlab analyzed satellite imagery 
of the world’s existing tree cover. By combining it with climate and soil data and excluding areas necessary
for human use, they determined Earth could support nearly one billion hectares 
of additional forest. That’s roughly 1.2 trillion trees. This staggering number surprised
the scientific community, prompting additional research. Scientists now cite a more conservative 
but still remarkable figure. By their revised estimates,
these restored ecosystems could capture anywhere from 100 to 200
billion tons of carbon, accounting for over one-sixth
of humanity’s carbon emissions. More than half of the potential
forest canopy for new restoration efforts 
can be found in just six countries. And the study can also provide insight
into existing restoration projects, like The Bonn Challenge, which aims to restore 350 million hectares
of forest by 2030. But this is where it gets complicated. Ecosystems are incredibly complex, and it’s unclear whether they’re best 
restored by human intervention. It’s possible the right thing 
to do for certain areas is to simply leave them alone. Additionally, some researchers
worry that restoring forests on this scale may have unintended 
consequences, like producing natural bio-chemicals at a pace that could actually 
accelerate climate change. And even if we succeed 
in restoring these areas, future generations would need
to protect them from the natural and economic forces
that previously depleted them. Taken together, these challenges
have damaged confidence in restoration projects worldwide. And the complexity 
of rebuilding ecosystems demonstrates how important 
it is to protect our existing forests. But hopefully, restoring 
some of these depleted regions will give us the data and conviction 
necessary to combat climate change on a larger scale. If we get it right, maybe these modern
trees will have time to grow into carbon carrying titans.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: About __ percent the dry weight of a tree consist of carbon
Options: A. 10, B. 30, C. 50, D. 70
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated age of the giant sequoia nicknamed General Sherman? Options: A. 1,000 years, B. 2,000 years, C. 2,500 years, D. 3,000 years Correct Option: None
Question 2: How much atmospheric carbon has General Sherman sequestered over its lifetime? Options: A. 100 tons, B. 1,400 tons, C. 14,000 tons, D. 140,000 tons Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the process by which plants, including trees, consume atmospheric carbon? Options: A. Respiration, B. Photosynthesis, C. Decomposition, D. Fermentation Correct Option: None
Question 4: What happens to the carbon stored in trees when they die and decay? Options: A. It is released back into the atmosphere, B. It is stored in the soil forever, C. It is converted into oxygen, D. It is absorbed by other plants Correct Option: None
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the most sustainable type of tree to plant for carbon sequestration? Options: A. Fast-growing, non-native species, B. Slow-growing, native species, C. Native species that already play a role in their local environment, D. Genetically engineered species Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the estimated number of additional trees that Earth could support, according to the Crowtherlab study? Options: A. 100 million, B. 1 billion, C. 1.2 trillion, D. 10 trillion Correct Option: None
Question 7: How much carbon could restored ecosystems capture, according to the revised estimates? Options: A. 10-20 billion tons, B. 100-200 billion tons, C. 1-2 trillion tons, D. 10-20 trillion tons Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the goal of The Bonn Challenge? Options: A. To restore 100 million hectares of forest by 2030, B. To restore 350 million hectares of forest by 2030, C. To plant 1 billion trees by 2030, D. To reduce carbon emissions by 50% by 2030 Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is a potential unintended consequence of restoring forests on a large scale? Options: A. Producing more oxygen, B. Reducing carbon emissions, C. Producing natural bio-chemicals that could accelerate climate change, D. Increasing biodiversity Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is it important to protect existing forests, according to the transcript? Options: A. Because they are more efficient at sequestering carbon than newly planted trees, B. Because they provide habitat for endangered species, C. Because they are more resilient to climate change, D. Because rebuilding ecosystems is complex and may have unintended consequences Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ asks about the percentage of a tree's dry weight that consists of carbon, while the generated MCQs cover various topics related to trees and carbon sequestration, but not this specific question.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the topic of carbon sequestration, I would say that Question 2 is the closest, but it's still not a good match.

A better approach would be to generate new MCQs that specifically target the topic of carbon composition in trees, rather than trying to match the ground truth MCQ with the existing generated MCQs.

If I had to provide an index, I would say -1 or None, indicating that there is no matching generated MCQ.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: To maximize the amount of carbon within a natural ecosystem composed of trees, it is better to harvest the trees __
Options: A. every five years, B. every year, C. every decade, D. never
Correct Option: D

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not a direct match, but Question 5 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the best approach to maximize carbon within a natural ecosystem composed of trees, and the correct answer is "never" harvest the trees. Question 5 asks about the most sustainable type of tree to plant for carbon sequestration, and the correct answer is "native species that already play a role in their local environment." While the questions are not identical, they both relate to the idea of preserving and utilizing natural ecosystems to maximize carbon sequestration.

However, a more relevant question that could match the ground truth MCQ would be one that asks about the best approach to managing existing trees for carbon sequestration. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs directly address this topic.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ, I would select Question 5, but with the understanding that it's not a perfect match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

on the planet. Nicknamed General Sherman, this giant sequoia has sequestered
roughly 1,400 tons of atmospheric carbon over its estimated 2,500 years on earth. Very few trees can compete

and decays, some of its carbon will be released
back into the air. A significant amount of CO2
is stored in the soil, where it can remain 
for thousands of years. But eventually, that carbon
also seeps back into the atmosphere. So if trees are going to help 
fight a long-term problem like climate change, they need to survive to sequester 
their carbon for the longest period possible, 
while also reproducing quickly. Is there one type of tree 
we could plant that meets these criteria? Some fast growing, long-lived, 
super sequestering species we could scatter worldwide? Not that we know of. But even if such a tree existed, it wouldn’t be a good 
long-term solution. Forests are complex networks 
of living organisms, and there’s no one species 
that can thrive in every ecosystem. The most sustainable trees to plant 
are always native ones; species that already play a role 
in their local environment. Preliminary research shows 
that ecosystems with a naturally occurring diversity
of trees have less competition for resources and better resist
climate change. This means we can’t just plant trees 
to draw down carbon; we need to restore depleted ecosystems. There are numerous regions
that have been clear cut or developed that are ripe for restoring. In 2019, a study led 
by Zurich’s Crowtherlab analyzed satellite imagery 
of the world’s existing tree cover. By combining it with climate and soil data and excluding areas necessary
for human use, they determined Earth could support nearly one billion hectares 
of additional forest. That’s roughly 1.2 trillion trees. This staggering number surprised
the scientific community, prompting additional research. Scientists now cite a more conservative 
but still remarkable figure. By their revised estimates,
these restored ecosystems could capture anywhere from 100 to 200
billion tons of carbon, accounting for over one-sixth
of humanity’s carbon emissions. More than half of the potential
forest canopy for new restoration efforts 
can be found in just six countries. And the study can also provide insight
into existing restoration projects, like The Bonn Challenge, which aims to restore 350 million hectares
of forest by 2030. But this is where it gets complicated. Ecosystems are incredibly complex, and it’s unclear whether they’re best 
restored by human intervention. It’s possible the right thing 
to do for certain areas is to simply leave them alone. Additionally, some researchers
worry that restoring forests on this scale may have unintended 
consequences, like producing natural bio-chemicals at a pace that could actually 
accelerate climate change. And even if we succeed 
in restoring these areas, future generations would need
to protect them from the natural and economic forces
that previously depleted them. Taken together, these challenges
have damaged confidence in restoration projects worldwide. And the complexity 
of rebuilding ecosystems demonstrates how important 
it is to protect our existing forests. But hopefully, restoring 
some of these depleted regions will give us the data and conviction 
necessary to combat climate change on a larger scale. If we get it right, maybe these modern
trees will have time to grow into carbon carrying titans.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Restoration involves the action of ___
Options: A. Planting the right tree in the right place, B. Re-growing endemic species, C. Protecting ecosystems, D. Monitoring ecosystems, E. Ensuring the sustainability of ecosystems considering both climate change and socio-economic aspects, F. Involving local communities, G. All the options together
Correct Option: G

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated age of the giant sequoia nicknamed General Sherman? Options: A. 1,000 years, B. 2,000 years, C. 2,500 years, D. 3,000 years Correct Option: None
Question 2: How much atmospheric carbon has General Sherman sequestered over its lifetime? Options: A. 100 tons, B. 1,400 tons, C. 14,000 tons, D. 140,000 tons Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the process by which plants, including trees, consume atmospheric carbon? Options: A. Respiration, B. Photosynthesis, C. Decomposition, D. Fermentation Correct Option: None
Question 4: What happens to the carbon stored in trees when they die and decay? Options: A. It is released back into the atmosphere, B. It is stored in the soil forever, C. It is converted into oxygen, D. It is absorbed by other plants Correct Option: None
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the most sustainable type of tree to plant for carbon sequestration? Options: A. Fast-growing, non-native species, B. Slow-growing, native species, C. Native species that already play a role in their local environment, D. Genetically engineered species Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the estimated number of additional trees that Earth could support, according to the Crowtherlab study? Options: A. 100 million, B. 1 billion, C. 1.2 trillion, D. 10 trillion Correct Option: None
Question 7: How much carbon could restored ecosystems capture, according to the revised estimates? Options: A. 10-20 billion tons, B. 100-200 billion tons, C. 1-2 trillion tons, D. 10-20 trillion tons Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the goal of The Bonn Challenge? Options: A. To restore 100 million hectares of forest by 2030, B. To restore 350 million hectares of forest by 2030, C. To plant 1 billion trees by 2030, D. To reduce carbon emissions by 50% by 2030 Correct Option: None

Because they provide habitat for endangered species, C. Because they are more resilient to climate change, D. Because rebuilding ecosystems is complex and may have unintended consequences Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ is focused on the concept of restoration and its involvement of multiple actions, whereas the generated MCQs cover various topics related to trees, carbon sequestration, and ecosystem restoration.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the topic of restoration, I would select Question 5: "According to the transcript, what is the most sustainable type of tree to plant for carbon sequestration?" This question is related to restoration, but it focuses on the type of tree to plant rather than the actions involved in restoration.

A more suitable generated MCQ that matches the ground truth MCQ's intent would be one that asks about the actions or strategies involved in restoration. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs directly address this topic.

Therefore, I will provide the index of Question 5 as the most similar generated MCQ, although it is not a perfect match:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Standing at almost 84 meters tall, this is the largest known living tree
on the planet. Nicknamed General Sherman, this giant sequoia has sequestered
roughly 1,400 tons of atmospheric carbon over its estimated 2,500 years on earth. Very few trees can compete 
with this carbon impact, but today, humanity produces more 
than 1,400 tons of carbon every minute. To combat climate change, we need to steeply reduce 
fossil fuel emissions, and draw down excess CO2 
to restore our atmosphere’s balance of greenhouse gases. But what can trees do to help
in this fight? And how do they sequester carbon 
in the first place? Like all plants, trees consume
atmospheric carbon through a chemical reaction 
called photosynthesis. This process uses energy 
from sunlight to convert water and carbon dioxide 
into oxygen and energy-storing carbohydrates. Plants then consume 
these carbohydrates in a reverse process called respiration, 
converting them to energy and releasing carbon 
back into the atmosphere. In trees, however, a large portion
of that carbon isn’t released, and instead, is stored 
as newly formed wood tissue. During their lifetimes, 
trees act as carbon vaults, and they continue to draw down carbon 
for as long as they grow. However, when a tree dies
and decays, some of its carbon will be released
back into the air. A significant amount of CO2
is stored in the soil, where it can remain 
for thousands of years. But eventually, that carbon
also seeps back into the atmosphere. So if trees are going to help 
fight a long-term problem like climate change, they need to survive to sequester 
their carbon for the longest period possible, 
while also reproducing quickly. Is there one type of tree 
we could plant that meets these criteria? Some fast growing, long-lived, 
super sequestering species we could scatter worldwide? Not that we know of. But even if such a tree existed, it wouldn’t be a good 
long-term solution. Forests are complex networks 
of living organisms, and there’s no one species 
that can thrive in every ecosystem. The most sustainable trees to plant 
are always native ones; species that already play a role 
in their local environment. Preliminary research shows 
that ecosystems with a naturally occurring diversity
of trees have less competition for resources and better resist
climate change. This means we can’t just plant trees 
to draw down carbon; we need to restore depleted ecosystems. There are numerous regions
that have been clear cut or developed that are ripe for restoring. In 2019, a study led 
by Zurich’s Crowtherlab analyzed satellite imagery 
of the world’s existing tree cover. By combining it with climate and soil data and excluding areas necessary
for human use, they determined Earth could support nearly one billion hectares 
of additional forest. That’s roughly 1.2 trillion trees. This staggering number surprised
the scientific community, prompting additional research. Scientists now cite a more conservative 
but still remarkable figure. By their revised estimates,
these restored ecosystems could capture anywhere from 100 to 200
billion tons of carbon, accounting for over one-sixth
of humanity’s carbon emissions. More than half of the potential
forest canopy for new restoration efforts 
can be found in just six countries. And the study can also provide insight
into existing restoration projects, like The Bonn Challenge, which aims to restore 350 million hectares
of forest by 2030. But this is where it gets complicated. Ecosystems are incredibly complex, and it’s unclear whether they’re best 
restored by human intervention. It’s possible the right thing 
to do for certain areas is to simply leave them alone. Additionally, some researchers
worry that restoring forests on this scale may have unintended 
consequences, like producing natural bio-chemicals at a pace that could actually 
accelerate climate change. And even if we succeed 
in restoring these areas, future generations would need
to protect them from the natural and economic forces
that previously depleted them. Taken together, these challenges
have damaged confidence in restoration projects worldwide. And the complexity 
of rebuilding ecosystems demonstrates how important 
it is to protect our existing forests. But hopefully, restoring 
some of these depleted regions will give us the data and conviction 
necessary to combat climate change on a larger scale. If we get it right, maybe these modern
trees will have time to grow into carbon carrying titans.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to the study presented, the restoration of ecosystems has the potential to capture at least ____ of the current atmospheric carbon content resulting from human activities.
Options: A. 1/20, B. 1/10, C. 1/6, D. 1/3
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 4: What happens to the carbon stored in trees when they die and decay? Options: A. It is released back into the atmosphere, B. It is stored in the soil forever, C. It is converted into oxygen, D. It is absorbed by other plants Correct Option: None
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the most sustainable type of tree to plant for carbon sequestration? Options: A. Fast-growing, non-native species, B. Slow-growing, native species, C. Native species that already play a role in their local environment, D. Genetically engineered species Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the estimated number of additional trees that Earth could support, according to the Crowtherlab study? Options: A. 100 million, B. 1 billion, C. 1.2 trillion, D. 10 trillion Correct Option: None
Question 7: How much carbon could restored ecosystems capture, according to the revised estimates? Options: A. 10-20 billion tons, B. 100-200 billion tons, C. 1-2 trillion tons, D. 10-20 trillion tons Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the goal of The Bonn Challenge? Options: A. To restore 100 million hectares of forest by 2030, B. To restore 350 million hectares of forest by 2030, C. To plant 1 billion trees by 2030, D. To reduce carbon emissions by 50% by 2030 Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is a potential unintended consequence of restoring forests on a large scale? Options: A. Producing more oxygen, B. Reducing carbon emissions, C. Producing natural bio-chemicals that could accelerate climate change, D. Increasing biodiversity Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is it important to protect existing forests, according to the transcript? Options: A. Because they are more efficient at sequestering carbon than newly planted trees, B. Because they provide habitat for endangered species, C. Because they are more resilient to climate change, D. Because rebuilding ecosystems is complex and may have unintended consequences Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7: How much carbon could restored ecosystems capture, according to the revised estimates? 

This question aligns with the ground truth MCQ in terms of content, as both questions discuss the potential carbon capture of restored ecosystems. The options in Question 7 also match the ground truth MCQ in terms of the correct answer (B. 100-200 billion tons) corresponding to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (C. 1/6, which is equivalent to 100-200 billion tons being one-sixth of humanity's carbon emissions).

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Ah, a witch hunt. Humans are tireless
in their pursuit of reason. "It’s 1950. Following threats from the communist 
governments of the Soviet Union and China, anti-communist sentiment in 
the United States is at an all-time high. Senator Joseph McCarthy claims 
he has a list of 205 communists in the US who are influencing government policy." Didn’t I just change the channel? Ah, I see. It’s a different witch hunt. "The senate forms a committee 
to investigate McCarthy’s claims. McCarthy names his first case: against prominent lawyer, judge,
and activist Dorothy Kenyon. He accuses her of membership to 28 
organizations that are communist fronts. Newspapers around the country 
rush to her defense, pointing out her vocally 
anti-communist record. The senate committee schedules 
a hearing anyway, and she has just five days to prepare." This is too much. If the government won’t be 
a voice of reason, I’ll have to. That’s better. I’m surprised you good legislators
have agreed to move this hearing forward. You’re falling prey to a type 
of argument from ignorance: assuming that a claim is true 
because it hasn’t been proven false. The claim being Senator McCarthy’s 
accusations against Judge Kenyon, for which he provided 
no legitimate evidence. Is that right? I thought so. Some of the so-called communist 
organizations he accused her of joining don’t even exist. To assume a claim is true 
because it hasn’t been proven false ignores many other possibilities: that it hasn’t been proven false yet, 
that it can’t be proven true or false, or that it isn’t completely true 
or completely false, to name a few. This leads to a handy rule of thumb: the burden of proof lies with the person
making the claim. In other words, you make the claim,
you supply the proof. If someone told you aliens exist, would you head off to find proof
that they don’t exist? Of course not. You’d tell that person 
to show you the UFO. The same applies when someone 
makes a claim that contradicts an established consensus. So when all the available evidence 
suggests that humans are causing an increase 
in global temperatures, the burden of proof has been fulfilled— if you disagree, it becomes 
your responsibility to prove otherwise. Right? Ah, I’ve gotten ahead of myself. You’ll see what I mean soon enough. Anyway, your legal system 
supposedly recognizes this rule— so what are you all doing here? "It’s July 17th, 1950, and the senate subcommittee has officially
dismissed all charges against Kenyon." As they should! "It’s 1954, and the senate 
has formally disciplined McCarthy." Took them long enough! "He will serve out the rest of his term, but will never again be elected 
to a public office. Because of his widespread 
anti-communist influence, hundreds of people have been incarcerated,
and thousands have lost their jobs." Ah! Look what the communists did!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Burden of Proof means that
Options: A. One who makes the claim has to prove it, B. Claim does not need the proof, C. Agreeing without proof, D. Claim has not been proven false
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the sentiment towards communism in the United States in 1950? Options: A. Pro-communist sentiment was on the rise., B. Anti-communist sentiment was at an all-time low., C. Anti-communist sentiment was at an all-time high., D. The sentiment towards communism was neutral. Correct Option: None
Question 2: Who claimed to have a list of 205 communists in the US who were influencing government policy? Options: A. Senator Joseph McCarthy, B. Judge Dorothy Kenyon, C. A prominent lawyer, D. A communist leader Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of argument is being referred to when assuming a claim is true because it hasn’t been proven false? Options: A. Argument from evidence, B. Argument from ignorance, C. Argument from reason, D. Argument from consensus Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the burden of proof rule of thumb mentioned in the transcript? Options: A. The burden of proof lies with the person denying the claim., B. The burden of proof lies with the person making the claim., C. The burden of proof lies with the government., D. The burden of proof lies with the majority. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the example given to illustrate the burden of proof rule? Options: A. Proving the existence of aliens, B. Proving the existence of UFOs, C. Proving that humans are causing an increase in global temperatures, D. Proving that someone is a communist Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the outcome of the senate subcommittee hearing against Judge Kenyon? Options: A. The charges were upheld, and she was found guilty., B. The charges were dismissed, but she was still penalized., C. The charges were dismissed, and she was cleared of all accusations., D. The hearing was postponed indefinitely. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What happened to Senator McCarthy in 1954? Options: A. He was re-elected to a public office., B. He was formally disciplined by the senate., C. He was impeached by the house of representatives., D. He resigned from his position. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the consequence of Senator McCarthy’s widespread anti-communist influence? Options: A. Hundreds of people were incarcerated, and thousands lost their jobs., B. Thousands of people were incarcerated, and hundreds lost their jobs., C. Hundreds of people were acquitted, and thousands regained their jobs., D. Thousands of people were acquitted, and hundreds regained their jobs. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was Judge Kenyon accused of by Senator McCarthy? Options: A. Membership to 28 organizations that were communist fronts, B. Membership to 205 communist organizations, C. Being a vocal anti-communist, D. Being a prominent lawyer and judge Correct Option: None
Question 10: What was the response of newspapers around the country to Senator McCarthy’s accusations against Judge Kenyon? Options: A. They supported Senator McCarthy’s claims., B. They were neutral and did not take a stance., C. They rushed to her defense, pointing out her vocally anti-communist record., D. They ignored the story altogether. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions are asking about the burden of proof, and both have options that define it as lying with the person making the claim (Option B in Question 4 and Option A in the ground truth MCQ). The other options in both questions are also similar in that they provide alternative, incorrect definitions of the burden of proof.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Ah, a witch hunt. Humans are tireless
in their pursuit of reason. "It’s 1950. Following threats from the communist 
governments of the Soviet Union and China, anti-communist sentiment in 
the United States is at an all-time high. Senator Joseph McCarthy claims 
he has a list of 205 communists in the US who are influencing government policy." Didn’t I just change the channel? Ah, I see. It’s a different witch hunt. "The senate forms a committee 
to investigate McCarthy’s claims. McCarthy names his first case: against prominent lawyer, judge,
and activist Dorothy Kenyon. He accuses her of membership to 28 
organizations that are communist fronts. Newspapers around the country 
rush to her defense, pointing out her vocally

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the sentiment towards communism in the United States in 1950? Options: A. Pro-communist sentiment was on the rise., B. Anti-communist sentiment was at an all-time low., C. Anti-communist sentiment was at an all-time high., D. The sentiment towards communism was neutral. Correct Option: None
Question 2: Who claimed to have a list of 205 communists in the US who were influencing government policy? Options: A. Senator Joseph McCarthy, B. Judge Dorothy Kenyon, C. A prominent lawyer, D. A communist leader Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of argument is being referred to when assuming a claim is true because it hasn’t been proven false? Options: A. Argument from evidence, B. Argument from ignorance, C. Argument from reason, D. Argument from consensus Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the burden of proof rule of thumb mentioned in the transcript? Options: A. The burden of proof lies with the person denying the claim., B. The burden of proof lies with the person making the claim., C. The burden of proof lies with the government., D. The burden of proof lies with the majority. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the example given to illustrate the burden of proof rule? Options: A. Proving the existence of aliens, B. Proving the existence of UFOs, C. Proving that humans are causing an increase in global temperatures, D. Proving that someone is a communist Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the outcome of the senate subcommittee hearing against Judge Kenyon? Options: A. The charges were upheld, and she was found guilty., B. The charges were dismissed, but she was still penalized., C. The charges were dismissed, and she was cleared of all accusations., D. The hearing was postponed indefinitely. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What happened to Senator McCarthy in 1954? Options: A. He was re-elected to a public office., B. He was formally disciplined by the senate., C. He was impeached by the house of representatives., D. He resigned from his position. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the consequence of Senator McCarthy’s widespread anti-communist influence? Options: A. Hundreds of people were incarcerated, and thousands lost their jobs., B. Thousands of people were incarcerated, and hundreds lost their jobs., C. Hundreds of people were acquitted, and thousands regained their jobs., D. Thousands of people were acquitted, and hundreds regained their jobs. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was Judge Kenyon accused of by Senator McCarthy? Options: A. Membership to 28 organizations that were communist fronts, B. Membership to 205 communist organizations, C. Being a vocal anti-communist, D. Being a prominent lawyer and judge Correct Option: None
Question 10: What was the response of newspapers around the country to Senator McCarthy’s accusations against Judge Kenyon? Options: A. They supported Senator McCarthy’s claims., B. They were neutral and did not take a stance., C. They rushed to her defense, pointing out her vocally anti-communist record., D. They ignored the story altogether. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions refer to the type of argument being made when assuming a claim is true because it hasn’t been proven false, and both have "Argument from Ignorance" as the correct answer. 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Ah, a witch hunt. Humans are tireless
in their pursuit of reason. "It’s 1950. Following threats from the communist 
governments of the Soviet Union and China, anti-communist sentiment in 
the United States is at an all-time high. Senator Joseph McCarthy claims 
he has a list of 205 communists in the US who are influencing government policy." Didn’t I just change the channel? Ah, I see. It’s a different witch hunt. "The senate forms a committee 
to investigate McCarthy’s claims. McCarthy names his first case: against prominent lawyer, judge,
and activist Dorothy Kenyon. He accuses her of membership to 28 
organizations that are communist fronts. Newspapers around the country 
rush to her defense, pointing out her vocally 
anti-communist record. The senate committee schedules 
a hearing anyway, and she has just five days to prepare." This is too much. If the government won’t be 
a voice of reason, I’ll have to. That’s better. I’m surprised you good legislators
have agreed to move this hearing forward. You’re falling prey to a type 
of argument from ignorance: assuming that a claim is true 
because it hasn’t been proven false. The claim being Senator McCarthy’s 
accusations against Judge Kenyon, for which he provided 
no legitimate evidence. Is that right? I thought so. Some of the so-called communist 
organizations he accused her of joining don’t even exist. To assume a claim is true 
because it hasn’t been proven false ignores many other possibilities: that it hasn’t been proven false yet, 
that it can’t be proven true or false, or that it isn’t completely true 
or completely false, to name a few. This leads to a handy rule of thumb: the burden of proof lies with the person
making the claim. In other words, you make the claim,
you supply the proof. If someone told you aliens exist, would you head off to find proof
that they don’t exist? Of course not. You’d tell that person 
to show you the UFO. The same applies when someone 
makes a claim that contradicts an established consensus. So when all the available evidence 
suggests that humans are causing an increase 
in global temperatures, the burden of proof has been fulfilled— if you disagree, it becomes 
your responsibility to prove otherwise. Right? Ah, I’ve gotten ahead of myself. You’ll see what I mean soon enough. Anyway, your legal system 
supposedly recognizes this rule— so what are you all doing here? "It’s July 17th, 1950, and the senate subcommittee has officially
dismissed all charges against Kenyon." As they should! "It’s 1954, and the senate 
has formally disciplined McCarthy." Took them long enough! "He will serve out the rest of his term, but will never again be elected 
to a public office. Because of his widespread 
anti-communist influence, hundreds of people have been incarcerated,
and thousands have lost their jobs." Ah! Look what the communists did!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: McCarthy’s claim against Dorothy Kenyon is based on which of the following fallacies
Options: A. Strawman, B. Ad Hominem, C. Burden of proof, D. Slippery slope
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the sentiment towards communism in the United States in 1950? Options: A. Pro-communist sentiment was on the rise., B. Anti-communist sentiment was at an all-time low., C. Anti-communist sentiment was at an all-time high., D. The sentiment towards communism was neutral. Correct Option: None
Question 2: Who claimed to have a list of 205 communists in the US who were influencing government policy? Options: A. Senator Joseph McCarthy, B. Judge Dorothy Kenyon, C. A prominent lawyer, D. A communist leader Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of argument is being referred to when assuming a claim is true because it hasn’t been proven false? Options: A. Argument from evidence, B. Argument from ignorance, C. Argument from reason, D. Argument from consensus Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the burden of proof rule of thumb mentioned in the transcript? Options: A. The burden of proof lies with the person denying the claim., B. The burden of proof lies with the person making the claim., C. The burden of proof lies with the government., D. The burden of proof lies with the majority. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the example given to illustrate the burden of proof rule? Options: A. Proving the existence of aliens, B. Proving the existence of UFOs, C. Proving that humans are causing an increase in global temperatures, D. Proving that someone is a communist Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the outcome of the senate subcommittee hearing against Judge Kenyon? Options: A. The charges were upheld, and she was found guilty., B. The charges were dismissed, but she was still penalized., C. The charges were dismissed, and she was cleared of all accusations., D. The hearing was postponed indefinitely. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What happened to Senator McCarthy in 1954? Options: A. He was re-elected to a public office., B. He was formally disciplined by the senate., C. He was impeached by the house of representatives., D. He resigned from his position. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the consequence of Senator McCarthy’s widespread anti-communist influence? Options: A. Hundreds of people were incarcerated, and thousands lost their jobs., B. Thousands of people were incarcerated, and hundreds lost their jobs., C. Hundreds of people were acquitted, and thousands regained their jobs., D. Thousands of people were acquitted, and hundreds regained their jobs. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was Judge Kenyon accused of by Senator McCarthy? Options: A. Membership to 28 organizations that were communist fronts, B. Membership to 205 communist organizations, C. Being a vocal anti-communist, D. Being a prominent lawyer and judge Correct Option: None
Question 10: What was the response of newspapers around the country to Senator McCarthy’s accusations against Judge Kenyon? Options: A. They supported Senator McCarthy’s claims., B. They were neutral and did not take a stance., C. They rushed to her defense, pointing out her vocally anti-communist record., D. They ignored the story altogether. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

Although Question 3 does not directly mention McCarthy's claim against Dorothy Kenyon, it does address the type of argument being referred to in the transcript, which is the same type of fallacy mentioned in the ground truth MCQ (i.e., assuming a claim is true because it hasn’t been proven false). This matches the intent of the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the fallacy in McCarthy's claim.

However, a more direct match can be found in Question 4, which addresses the burden of proof rule mentioned in the transcript. This rule is closely related to the fallacy mentioned in the ground truth MCQ, and the correct option (B) directly corresponds to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (C).

Considering both options, Question 4 is a more direct match to the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On the edge of the vast Sahara desert, citizens snuck out of the city of Timbuktu and took to the wilderness. They buried chests in the desert sand,
hid them in caves, and sealed them in secret rooms. Inside these chests was a treasure 
more valuable than gold: the city’s ancient books. Founded around 1100 CE 
in what is now Mali, the city of Timbuktu started 
out as an unremarkable trading post. But its unique location 
soon changed that. Timbuktu marked the intersection
of two essential trade routes, where caravans bringing 
salt across the Sahara met with traders bringing gold
from the African interior. By the late 1300s, these trade routes 
made Timbuktu rich, and the city’s rulers, 
the kings of the Mali Empire, built monuments and academies
that drew scholars from Egypt, Spain, and Morocco. The city’s prime location also made
it a target for warlords and conquerors. As the Mali Empire declined, 
one of its domains, Songhai, began to gain power. In 1468, the Songhai king 
conquered Timbuktu, burning buildings and murdering scholars. But in time, intellectual life 
in the city flourished again. The reign of the second king 
of the Songhai Empire, Askia Mohammed Toure, marked the beginning of a golden age 
in Timbuktu. He reversed his predecessor’s
regressive policies and encouraged learning. The Songhai rulers and most of Timbuktu’s 
population were Muslim, and the scholars of Timbuktu 
studied Islam alongside secular topics 
like mathematics and philosophy. In the libraries of Timbuktu, tracts of Greek philosophy stood
alongside the writings of local historians, scientists,
and poets. The city’s most prominent scholar,
Ahmed Baba, challenged prevailing opinions
on subjects ranging from smoking to slavery. Gold and salt trade had funded
the city’s transformation into a center of learning. Now, the products 
of that intellectual culture became the most sought-after 
commodity. With paper from faraway Venice and vibrant ink from local plants
and minerals, the scribes of Timbuktu produced 
texts in both Arabic and local languages. Written in calligraphy and decorated
with intricate geometric designs, the books of Timbuktu were in demand
among the wealthiest members of society. In 1591, the golden age 
came to an abrupt end when the Moroccan king 
captured Timbuktu. Moroccan forces imprisoned 
Ahmed Baba and other prominent scholars and confiscated their libraries. In the centuries that followed, the city 
weathered a succession of conquests. In the mid-1800s, 
Sufi Jihadists occupied Timbuktu and destroyed many non-religious
manuscripts. 1894, French colonial forces seized
control of the city, stealing even more manuscripts
and sending them to Europe. French became the official language
taught in schools, and new generations in Timbuktu couldn’t read the Arabic manuscripts 
that remained. Through it all, the literary tradition
of Timbuktu didn’t die— it went underground. Some families built secret libraries
in their homes, or buried the books in their gardens. Others stashed them in abandoned caves 
or holes in the desert. The priceless manuscripts of Timbuktu dispersed to villages 
throughout the surrounding area, where regular citizens guarded 
them for hundreds of years. As desertification and war 
impoverished the region, families held on to the ancient books even as they faced desperate poverty
and near-starvation. Even today, the struggle to protect
the books continues. From the 1980s to the early 2000s, Timbuktu scholar Abdel Kader Haidara
painstakingly retrieved hidden manuscripts from all over northern Mali 
and brought them back to Timbuktu. But in 2012, civil war in Mali 
once again threatened the manuscripts, most of which were evacuated
to nearby Bamako. Their future remains uncertain, as they face both human 
and environmental threats. These books represent our best—
and often only— sources on the pre-colonial history
of the region. Many of them have never been 
read by modern scholars, and still more remain lost 
or hidden in the desert. At stake in the efforts to protect
them is the history they contain— and the efforts of countless generations
to protect that history from being lost.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Timbuktu was founded around
Options: A. 1200 CE, B. 1100 CE, C. 1000 CE, D. 1300 CE
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what year was the city of Timbuktu founded? Options: A. 1200 CE, B. 1100 CE, C. 1300 CE, D. 1400 CE Correct Option: None
Question 2: What made Timbuktu a unique and valuable location? Options: A. Its proximity to the African coast, B. Its location at the intersection of two essential trade routes, C. Its position as the capital of the Mali Empire, D. Its natural resources Correct Option: None
Question 3: Who conquered Timbuktu in 1468 and burned buildings and murdered scholars? Options: A. The king of the Mali Empire, B. The Songhai king, C. The Moroccan king, D. The French colonial forces Correct Option: None
Question 4: Who reversed his predecessor's regressive policies and encouraged learning in Timbuktu? Options: A. Ahmed Baba, B. Askia Mohammed Toure, C. The king of the Mali Empire, D. The Moroccan king Correct Option: None
Question 5: What were the main subjects studied by scholars in Timbuktu? Options: A. Only Islamic studies, B. Only secular topics like mathematics and philosophy, C. A combination of Islamic studies and secular topics, D. Only local history and poetry Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who was the city's most prominent scholar and challenged prevailing opinions on various subjects? Options: A. Ahmed Baba, B. Askia Mohammed Toure, C. Abdel Kader Haidara, D. The king of the Mali Empire Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the main commodity that became sought after in Timbuktu during its golden age? Options: A. Gold, B. Salt, C. Books and manuscripts, D. Other local products Correct Option: None
Question 8: Who captured Timbuktu in 1591 and imprisoned prominent scholars and confiscated their libraries? Options: A. The Songhai king, B. The Moroccan king, C. The French colonial forces, D. The Sufi Jihadists Correct Option: None
Question 9: What happened to the manuscripts of Timbuktu during the centuries of conquest and occupation? Options: A. They were all destroyed, B. They were all preserved and protected, C. Some were destroyed, while others were hidden and protected by local citizens, D. They were all taken to Europe Correct Option: None
Question 10: Who painstakingly retrieved hidden manuscripts from all over northern Mali and brought them back to Timbuktu from the 1980s to the early 2000s? Options: A. Ahmed Baba, B. Askia Mohammed Toure, C. Abdel Kader Haidara, D. The king of the Mali Empire Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1: "In what year was the city of Timbuktu founded?" 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to determine the founding year of Timbuktu. Although the options in Question 1 are slightly different from the ground truth MCQ, they both include the correct answer, 1100 CE (Option B in the ground truth MCQ).

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

to protect that history from being lost.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On the edge of the vast Sahara desert, citizens snuck out of the city of Timbuktu and took to the wilderness. They buried chests in the desert sand,
hid them in caves, and sealed them in secret rooms. Inside these chests was a treasure 
more valuable than gold: the city’s ancient books. Founded around 1100 CE 
in what is now Mali, the city of Timbuktu started 
out as an unremarkable trading post. But its unique location 
soon changed that. Timbuktu marked the intersection
of two essential trade routes, where caravans bringing 
salt across the Sahara met with traders bringing gold
from the African interior. By the late 1300s, these trade routes 
made Timbuktu rich, and the city’s rulers, 
the kings of the Mali Empire, built monuments and academies
that drew scholars from Egypt, Spain, and Morocco. The city’s prime location also made
it a target for warlords and conquerors. As the Mali Empire declined,

conquered Timbuktu, burning buildings and murdering scholars. But in time, intellectual life 
in the city flourished again. The reign of the second king 
of the Songhai Empire, Askia Mohammed Toure, marked the beginning of a golden age 
in Timbuktu. He reversed his predecessor’s
regressive policies and encouraged learning. The Songhai rulers and most of Timbuktu’s 
population were Muslim, and the scholars of Timbuktu 
studied Islam alongside secular topics 
like mathematics and philosophy. In the libraries of Timbuktu, tracts of Greek philosophy stood
alongside the writings of local historians, scientists,
and poets. The city’s most prominent scholar,
Ahmed Baba, challenged prevailing opinions
on subjects ranging from smoking to slavery. Gold and salt trade had funded

of that intellectual culture became the most sought-after 
commodity. With paper from faraway Venice and vibrant ink from local plants
and minerals, the scribes of Timbuktu produced 
texts in both Arabic and local languages. Written in calligraphy and decorated

captured Timbuktu. Moroccan forces imprisoned 
Ahmed Baba and other prominent scholars and confiscated their libraries. In the centuries that followed, the city 
weathered a succession of conquests. In the mid-1800s,

and sending them to Europe. French became the official language

to protect that history from being lost.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The king from which domain conquered Timbuktu in 1468?
Options: A. Morocco, B. Mali, C. Songhai, D. Venice
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what year was the city of Timbuktu founded? Options: A. 1200 CE, B. 1100 CE, C. 1300 CE, D. 1400 CE Correct Option: None
Question 2: What made Timbuktu a unique and valuable location? Options: A. Its proximity to the African coast, B. Its location at the intersection of two essential trade routes, C. Its position as the capital of the Mali Empire, D. Its natural resources Correct Option: None
Question 3: Who conquered Timbuktu in 1468 and burned buildings and murdered scholars? Options: A. The king of the Mali Empire, B. The Songhai king, C. The Moroccan king, D. The French colonial forces Correct Option: None
Question 4: Who reversed his predecessor's regressive policies and encouraged learning in Timbuktu? Options: A. Ahmed Baba, B. Askia Mohammed Toure, C. The king of the Mali Empire, D. The Moroccan king Correct Option: None
Question 5: What were the main subjects studied by scholars in Timbuktu? Options: A. Only Islamic studies, B. Only secular topics like mathematics and philosophy, C. A combination of Islamic studies and secular topics, D. Only local history and poetry Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who was the city's most prominent scholar and challenged prevailing opinions on various subjects? Options: A. Ahmed Baba, B. Askia Mohammed Toure, C. Abdel Kader Haidara, D. The king of the Mali Empire Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the main commodity that became sought after in Timbuktu during its golden age? Options: A. Gold, B. Salt, C. Books and manuscripts, D. Other local products Correct Option: None
Question 8: Who captured Timbuktu in 1591 and imprisoned prominent scholars and confiscated their libraries? Options: A. The Songhai king, B. The Moroccan king, C. The French colonial forces, D. The Sufi Jihadists Correct Option: None
Question 9: What happened to the manuscripts of Timbuktu during the centuries of conquest and occupation? Options: A. They were all destroyed, B. They were all preserved and protected, C. Some were destroyed, while others were hidden and protected by local citizens, D. They were all taken to Europe Correct Option: None
Question 10: Who painstakingly retrieved hidden manuscripts from all over northern Mali and brought them back to Timbuktu from the 1980s to the early 2000s? Options: A. Ahmed Baba, B. Askia Mohammed Toure, C. Abdel Kader Haidara, D. The king of the Mali Empire Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3: Who conquered Timbuktu in 1468 and burned buildings and murdered scholars? 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, asking about the king who conquered Timbuktu in 1468. Although the options are not identical, the correct answer in Question 3 (B. The Songhai king) matches the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (C. Songhai).

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On the edge of the vast Sahara desert, citizens snuck out of the city of Timbuktu and took to the wilderness. They buried chests in the desert sand,
hid them in caves, and sealed them in secret rooms. Inside these chests was a treasure 
more valuable than gold: the city’s ancient books. Founded around 1100 CE 
in what is now Mali, the city of Timbuktu started 
out as an unremarkable trading post. But its unique location 
soon changed that. Timbuktu marked the intersection
of two essential trade routes, where caravans bringing 
salt across the Sahara met with traders bringing gold
from the African interior. By the late 1300s, these trade routes 
made Timbuktu rich, and the city’s rulers, 
the kings of the Mali Empire, built monuments and academies
that drew scholars from Egypt, Spain, and Morocco. The city’s prime location also made
it a target for warlords and conquerors. As the Mali Empire declined, 
one of its domains, Songhai, began to gain power. In 1468, the Songhai king 
conquered Timbuktu, burning buildings and murdering scholars. But in time, intellectual life 
in the city flourished again. The reign of the second king 
of the Songhai Empire, Askia Mohammed Toure, marked the beginning of a golden age 
in Timbuktu. He reversed his predecessor’s
regressive policies and encouraged learning. The Songhai rulers and most of Timbuktu’s 
population were Muslim, and the scholars of Timbuktu 
studied Islam alongside secular topics 
like mathematics and philosophy. In the libraries of Timbuktu, tracts of Greek philosophy stood
alongside the writings of local historians, scientists,
and poets. The city’s most prominent scholar,
Ahmed Baba, challenged prevailing opinions
on subjects ranging from smoking to slavery. Gold and salt trade had funded
the city’s transformation into a center of learning. Now, the products 
of that intellectual culture became the most sought-after 
commodity. With paper from faraway Venice and vibrant ink from local plants
and minerals, the scribes of Timbuktu produced 
texts in both Arabic and local languages. Written in calligraphy and decorated
with intricate geometric designs, the books of Timbuktu were in demand
among the wealthiest members of society. In 1591, the golden age 
came to an abrupt end when the Moroccan king 
captured Timbuktu. Moroccan forces imprisoned 
Ahmed Baba and other prominent scholars and confiscated their libraries. In the centuries that followed, the city 
weathered a succession of conquests. In the mid-1800s, 
Sufi Jihadists occupied Timbuktu and destroyed many non-religious
manuscripts. 1894, French colonial forces seized
control of the city, stealing even more manuscripts
and sending them to Europe. French became the official language
taught in schools, and new generations in Timbuktu couldn’t read the Arabic manuscripts 
that remained. Through it all, the literary tradition
of Timbuktu didn’t die— it went underground. Some families built secret libraries
in their homes, or buried the books in their gardens. Others stashed them in abandoned caves 
or holes in the desert. The priceless manuscripts of Timbuktu dispersed to villages 
throughout the surrounding area, where regular citizens guarded 
them for hundreds of years. As desertification and war 
impoverished the region, families held on to the ancient books even as they faced desperate poverty
and near-starvation. Even today, the struggle to protect
the books continues. From the 1980s to the early 2000s, Timbuktu scholar Abdel Kader Haidara
painstakingly retrieved hidden manuscripts from all over northern Mali 
and brought them back to Timbuktu. But in 2012, civil war in Mali 
once again threatened the manuscripts, most of which were evacuated
to nearby Bamako. Their future remains uncertain, as they face both human 
and environmental threats. These books represent our best—
and often only— sources on the pre-colonial history
of the region. Many of them have never been 
read by modern scholars, and still more remain lost 
or hidden in the desert. At stake in the efforts to protect
them is the history they contain— and the efforts of countless generations
to protect that history from being lost.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did Askia Mohammed Toure encourage when he took over?
Options: A. beating, B. learning, C. bathing, D. eating
Correct Option: B

Question 6: Who was the city's most prominent scholar and challenged prevailing opinions on various subjects? Options: A. Ahmed Baba, B. Askia Mohammed Toure, C. Abdel Kader Haidara, D. The king of the Mali Empire Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the main commodity that became sought after in Timbuktu during its golden age? Options: A. Gold, B. Salt, C. Books and manuscripts, D. Other local products Correct Option: None
Question 8: Who captured Timbuktu in 1591 and imprisoned prominent scholars and confiscated their libraries? Options: A. The Songhai king, B. The Moroccan king, C. The French colonial forces, D. The Sufi Jihadists Correct Option: None

Some were destroyed, while others were hidden and protected by local citizens, D. They were all taken to Europe Correct Option: None

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On the edge of the vast Sahara desert, citizens snuck out of the city of Timbuktu and took to the wilderness. They buried chests in the desert sand,
hid them in caves, and sealed them in secret rooms. Inside these chests was a treasure 
more valuable than gold: the city’s ancient books. Founded around 1100 CE 
in what is now Mali, the city of Timbuktu started 
out as an unremarkable trading post. But its unique location 
soon changed that. Timbuktu marked the intersection
of two essential trade routes, where caravans bringing 
salt across the Sahara met with traders bringing gold
from the African interior. By the late 1300s, these trade routes 
made Timbuktu rich, and the city’s rulers,

that drew scholars from Egypt, Spain, and Morocco. The city’s prime location also made
it a target for warlords and conquerors. As the Mali Empire declined,

in the city flourished again. The reign of the second king 
of the Songhai Empire, Askia Mohammed Toure, marked the beginning of a golden age

and minerals, the scribes of Timbuktu produced

with intricate geometric designs, the books of Timbuktu were in demand
among the wealthiest members of society. In 1591, the golden age 
came to an abrupt end when the Moroccan king 
captured Timbuktu. Moroccan forces imprisoned 
Ahmed Baba and other prominent scholars and confiscated their libraries. In the centuries that followed, the city 
weathered a succession of conquests. In the mid-1800s, 
Sufi Jihadists occupied Timbuktu and destroyed many non-religious
manuscripts. 1894, French colonial forces seized
control of the city, stealing even more manuscripts
and sending them to Europe. French became the official language
taught in schools, and new generations in Timbuktu couldn’t read the Arabic manuscripts 
that remained. Through it all, the literary tradition
of Timbuktu didn’t die— it went underground. Some families built secret libraries
in their homes, or buried the books in their gardens. Others stashed them in abandoned caves 
or holes in the desert. The priceless manuscripts of Timbuktu dispersed to villages 
throughout the surrounding area, where regular citizens guarded 
them for hundreds of years. As desertification and war 
impoverished the region, families held on to the ancient books even as they faced desperate poverty
and near-starvation. Even today, the struggle to protect
the books continues. From the 1980s to the early 2000s, Timbuktu scholar Abdel Kader Haidara
painstakingly retrieved hidden manuscripts from all over northern Mali 
and brought them back to Timbuktu. But in 2012, civil war in Mali 
once again threatened the manuscripts, most of which were evacuated
to nearby Bamako. Their future remains uncertain, as they face both human 
and environmental threats. These books represent our best—
and often only— sources on the pre-colonial history
of the region. Many of them have never been 
read by modern scholars, and still more remain lost 
or hidden in the desert. At stake in the efforts to protect
them is the history they contain— and the efforts of countless generations
to protect that history from being lost.
